Gojira JumpChain
ゴジラ
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In 1954, 9 years after the disastrous events that would end Japan’s involvement in World War 2, there was another nuclear incident in the Pacific Ocean. A Japanese freighter disappeared off of the coast of Odo Island and all subsequent search parties disappeared along with it. Fish in the area rapidly decline until they are all but gone. The Japanese government has little idea about what could be happening, but an elder in a small fishing village on Odo has the answer. Gojira is the name of the monster that now haunts the shores of Japan. Mutated and enraged by the radiation of the nuclear attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, as well as the nuclear tests near Bikini Atoll, Gojira has come to wreak his horrible vengeance on humanity; starting with the unsuspecting people of Japan. You arrive here a few days before the first incident with the Japanese freighter.

boardgame.name: Thalara: The Last Artifacts
boardgame.description:
Welcome to the world of Thalara! The world's magic is dwindling away - fight for the last artifacts to preserve your power before it's too late!

Thalara: The Last Artifacts is a fast-paced, highly interactive, asymmetric hand-building strategy card game with low luck and a special twist.

The game features a unique hand-locking mechanic: Each round more of your cards get "locked to your hand" to be used in each subsequent round. Thalara's core is a hand building game where you don't just select the cards you want - you fight for them!

No more luck of the draw: You select every single card you draw from your personal card pool. Every spell is available all the time and on the table right in front of you.

You can choose any character that fits your playstyle and always have a fair chance to win. There are characters that can be learned in seconds while others take a lifetime to master.

—description from the description

boardgame.name: MOD: Genel Kültür Oyunu
boardgame.description:
MOD is a trivia game supported by a mobile application that contains questions in five different categories with two different game options.

The game features a mobile device, double-sided gaming platform and five pawns in different colours. The current category and difficulty on the platform are selected in the application to see the question to be answered. The game platform consists of three rings and is based on the level of difficulties with the questions.

Each round, the player is asked three questions. Players will receive a random category and wildcard by pressing the dice button in the app and select a difficulty level of their choice. Each well-known question is advanced by one household, by medium household by two households, and by difficult households by three households.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Drifter
boardgame.description:
The Drifter is a solitaire, story, dice game based in the fictional wild west.

The drifter is reminiscent of games like Barbarian Prince (1980), where every game is a unique story experience.

You are a gunslinger who has been living a hazy existence. Your brief time in this world has been mostly spent on the outside of the law, killing, stealing, carousing with undesirables, living a dangerous life full of excess and violence. Recently, you feel life might have more to offer. You know this way of life will not last and now are looking to maybe put your wild ways away, buy a ranch and settle into obscurity. You determined you need $300 and are willing to get it by any means you feel necessary.

Will you fall victim to one of the endless dangers that lurk in the wild west or will you enjoy your remaining days in a serene retirement, tending to your ranch?
Find out as The Drifter.

—description from the designer

boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In 2065, Earth lies in ruins, largely abandoned in the aftermath of a one sided conflict between humans and the mysterious entities called the “Phantoms”. 34 years ago, the Leonid Meteor struck the planet, and from the smoldering crater, alien creatures known as the Phantoms spread out across the planet. First contact with the alien species proved fatal to humans, and no attempt at establishing a means of communication had any effect, the Phantoms ignored the humans and continued to spread from the impact site. Unable to contain the Phantoms, humans across the world were forced to retreat. 14 years after the impact, technology finally caught up, and strongholds were built, protected by mighty walls sustained by a new energy source known as “bio-etheric energy”. The aptly named barrier cities became the last bastions of human civilization as the global government body known as the UNSC worked on a formal strategy with the intention of reclaiming the planet from the alien invaders.

Humanity was never the apex predator of this planet. The masters of the world were merely sleeping, hibernating until the world was full of prey once more. The reign of fire began decades ago when the only male dragon in the world was disturbed from it’s rest, waking and spawning an ever growing swarm of powerful flying beasts. They took the human world by storm, wiping out countless cities and overwhelming the world’s military with endless numbers and power. Years of hopeless battle raged on but eventually humanity was crushed.

Decades passed since the day it all began and what little is left of humanity is spread across the world in small pockets, tiny villages and towns doing their best to stay quiet, keep their eyes on the sky and keep surviving.

boardgame.name: Return To Sender: The Mail Game
boardgame.description:
Also styled as “Return To Sender” The Mail Game and The New Post Office Game!

This appears to be a reasonably straightforward 'roll and move' style game - or more accurately 'spin and move' since a spinner is provided with the game - it is assembled in the centre of the board itself. It contains a fold out board, instructions, and playing pieces in (at least) five colours - one for each player. It is themed on the delivery of mail through the US postal service.

Players each start their letter tokens on the "Sender - start here" space on the outermost coil of the spiral, and move around a spiral course of 61 spaces, until reaching one of the blue "Mail delivered - game won" space. Unusually, the innermost coil of the spiral contains five of these winning spaces (interspersed with hazard spaces), and there is one more winning space at the end of the second coil. There are two kinds of hazard spaces (yellow = lose a turn; red = go back), as well as green 'do nothing' spaces, and further blue spaces on which nothing happens when landed upon, but which serve as location markers for some of the 'go back' hazards.

The box states "A Thomas Game - manufactured by American Game & Dice manufacturing Co., Cleveland, Ohio", and the rules leaflet says "A Thomas Game, 4191 Weymouth Road, Medina, Ohio, 44256-9247".

—user summary

boardgame.name: Carbonfighters
boardgame.description:
Carbonfighters is a resource management racing board game for 2-6 players simulating a five Grand Prix formula racing season during which you constantly develope your racecar and pitcrew while competing to be the champion by winning the most GPs.

Grands Prix take place on five different modular tracks made up from hexa tiles. As the season evolves tracks become more and more complex. There are two kinds of resources: tyres and fuel. You spend them according to the racetrack tiles you move onto and the development state of your vehicle. You need to pick a driver too who’s resource saving abilities you fancy.

At the beginning of each Grand Prix you choose from two strategies. According to your decision movement cards are dealt to you with movement points on them to move forward on the track. Your strategy decides if you can use higher or lower numbered movement cards.

Qualifying determines the starting order of the players’ cars. A Grand Prix consists of rounds until someone reaches the final tile. Each round consists of the following steps:

Choosing a card or using the slipstream card.
Spending resources
Resolving action situation when cars are in front
Announcing pit stops to refill your resources and activate driver abilities


After the Grand Prix is finished medals are given to the first three players. All players get also victory points according to how many tiles they have reached. These are for developing your car and/or pitcrew before the next Grand Prix.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Home Port
boardgame.description:
Home Port is a shipping themed board game, designed to bring people together around a journey of fun, concentration and celebration. Home Port incorporates economic principles such as supply and demand, cash-flow, buying and selling of both natural resources and containerized goods, as well as various real-life applications affecting the world of shipping and international trade. The pick-up-and-delivery mechanism adds an exciting flow to the game, while the systematic movement of sailing ships across the map creates an awareness of physical and time constraints. The game plays 2-5 players for about 60-90 minutes with the aim of acquiring 7 Game Point Tokens first, combining strategic planning, fleet expansion, and financial acceleration.
All aboard!! Home Port is shipping in some serious fun!

boardgame.name: 6つの祭壇 (The Six Sacred Altars)
boardgame.description:
6つの祭壇 (Muttsu no saidan) The Six Sacred Altars is a Japanese game for two players. During the game, players play cards to the table, trying to control the total value in play. The deck contains number cards and action cards which affect the results.

Each player is dealt 6 cards to their hand. They then take turns to either play a card face up or discard a card (drawing a new card from the deck each time), or discard all six cards and redraw.

Once six cards have been played, the round ends and the total worked out from the cards on the table.

If the total is equal or over 10, the start player (attacker) scores 2 points. Otherwise, the second player (defender) scores 1 point. The players now swap roles of attack and defence and continue.

The first player to win a 2 point margin wins the match.
user summary

A Card game, two players compete changing offense and defense on each round. Each player plays a card from hand alternately. Once six cards has played, a winner will be chosen according to the sum the numbers on them. The action cards will be the key to victory!
It's a compact but full-of-compete-feeling game.

攻守交代しながら戦うカードゲームです。
手札を交互に出し6枚目が並んだ時点の場の合計値で勝敗決定します。
アクションカードが、場を揺るがす勝敗の鍵に！
コンパクトながらしっかり、バトルしてる感を味わえます✨

boardgame.name: Tegel Manor (The Judges Guild Classic Reborn) (S&W)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

First published in 1977, Tegel Manor is the oldest of “Haunted House” adventures in fantasy roleplaying. The Manor is a sprawling edifice of 250+ rooms filled with tricks, traps, puzzles, monsters, and situations both humorous and horrific. Like the classic haunted house, not much of Tegel Manor makes logical sense, but it’s still as dangerous as adventuring can get. The huge manor house has been the curse of its owners, the Rump family, for generations – no matter how many times they have tried to get rid of it, the ownership manages to come back to them. This intertwined and sinister relationship between the house and its chosen family is a history of horror, evil, and greed. There is a lot for the characters to learn about the curse, and their knowledge might just keep them alive long enough to tell the tale.

boardgame.name: Vis ex Machina
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

5E Character options inspired by The Academy of Magic and Engineering

The prestigious Academy instructs dozens of the brightest pupils, providing the expertise needed to usher in a new age of engineering wonders, magical theory, and blending the two into truly amazing feats of accomplishment. From the mountain peaks of the city-state of Bridged City, the Academy stands as an example of the innovative, mystical construction techniques developed and taught since the Divine Wars.

The most accomplished minds at the Academy pioneer advancements in blending magic with mechanically focused magic. Machinae are specially crafted mechanical magic items. These creations, based on the formulae of established crafts, are capable of even more wondrous feats of power. But...only the trained may reliably use these complex devices.

Vis ex Machina includes a small selection of subclasses, feats, and other options for characters who have attended such an Academy and absorbed its curriculum. The system for creating and using machinae is detailed and includes a few examples of the mechanical magic items.

boardgame.name: The F.R.P. Character Card
Fantasy Role Playing Cards
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The F.R.P. Character Card was an early character sheet intended to support "E.P.T., D & D, T & T, C & S, Space Quest, Runequest," etc.

The cards were 5" x 8" and had 1/8" holes punched around the entire border to enable rapid selection of an individual card from a large stack. For example, cards for a peculiar game system would retain a specific hole intact - cards for all other game systems would have that hole clipped through from the card margin. An included needle then could be pushed through the entire stack of aligned cards, and only the ones with the hole intact would remain on the needle (others would fall off).

The holes on the different edges of the card were numbered in separate, letter-coded series.

The cards were sold in bagged sets of 40 or 80, and each set included a needle (something like a wire safety-pin) and a special punch tool.

boardgame.name: Moonshell
boardgame.description:
In the strategy puzzle game Moonshell, you play as a mermaid who is shifting tides in your direction to collect valuable seashells and create a stunning collection.

In more detail, the game board features a 5x5 array of colorful seashells of different types. Five public objectives are revealed, showing players the seashells they want to collect — whether by type, color, or overall pattern — on their 3x4 treasure chest board. You receive two secret objectives, keeping one and discarding the other. If you wish, you can play with each player taking a mermaid character (each of which has a unique power) and a moonshell, which serves as a wild seashell.

On a turn, you take three actions, repeating actions if you like. The actions are:


Rotate: Turn the game board 90º in the direction of the tide.
Pull 2: If the two rock spaces on the side of the game board next to you don't have any seashells on them, choose a column, place the first two seashells in this column on these rocks, slide the remaining seashells toward you, then draw from the supply bag to fill the empty spaces.
Collect: Take a seashell from a rock in front of you, and add it to your treasure chest, sliding the seashell to the bottom of the column in which you place it.


If the bag runs out of seashell tiles, add the sea urchin tiles to the bag and continue playing. When someone has filled their treasure chest with twelve tiles, finish the round, then score. The "trove" objective scores only for the player who has the most seashells of that type or color, whereas the other four types of objectives — collector, array, pairs, composition — can be scored by each player, sometimes multiple times. You also score 1 point for each sea urchin and if you achieved your secret objective, you score for that, too. Whoever scores the most points wins.

boardgame.name: ブラウメア (BLAUMARE)
Buraumea
boardgame.description:
ブラウメア (Buraumea) BLAUMARE is a Japanese co-operative word game.

Mito is trapped in her bad dream. To escape from it, she must gather images of the reality by asking herself how the reality looks like. But the nightmare might be showing her false images to misdirect her.

In the game of BLAUMARE, players divided into two forces. One player is the nightmare who try to misdirect opponents. The others represent one girl named Mito who is trying to escape from her dream. Mito's side wins if they successfully make three pairs of cards of different symbols.

At the beginning of the game, players are secretly assigned their roles. One player is the nightmare, and the others are Mito. Each player is dealt a certain number of image cards and one clue card. Such as 'number', 'color', etc. is written in clue cards. If you have 'number' clue card, you may only ask about numbers, such as "is the reality related to six?"

When you try to make a pair, you try to find another player who has the identical image of reality (namely, who has the identical card as one of yours). First, you ask everyone else what the reality is related, complying with your clue card. Other players say "Yes" or "No". Then you target a player who said "Yes". Both you and that player place the card which they think is identical with each other face-down.

In a later turn, you may reveal the two cards. If these are identical, Mito's side takes the pair which can count toward victory. Otherwise the nightmare takes these two cards.

Mito's side wins when they successfully make three pairs of cards with different symbols. The nightmare wins when they have taken three pairs of cards with different symbols or six cards with the same symbol, or when the image deck runs out.

As the nightmare, you should try to misdirect Mito's side indicating that you have the right image, even if you don't have. But you shouldn't be obvious.

サマータイムメモリー (SUMMER TIME MEMORY)
boardgame.description:
サマータイムメモリー (Sama- Taimu Memori-) SUMMER TIME MEMORY is a memory game with card-specific effects. Its theme is enjoying summer vacation.

At the beginning of the game, ten cards are placed on the table face-down.

During your turn, you draw a card from the top of the draw pile. If the card has special effect, you may reveal the card to activate the effect. Otherwise place it on the table face-down.

Then you reveal two cards on the table. If these cards match, you take them and score victory points. Repeat the process until you reveal different cards.

The game ends when three cards "お", "わ", and "り", which form the word "おわり (end)", are revealed, or when the draw pile is depleted. The highest scorer wins the game.

boardgame.name: Necromolds: Monster Battles
boardgame.description:
Behold, the Necromolds! Banned by feudal wizards and banished from mortal hands, these evil spellbooks and the monsters they hold have once again returned to wreak havoc on humankind!

In Necromolds: Monster Battles, players build and battle golem armies using their Necromold spellbooks and containers of spell clay. The stronger the monster, the more clay it demands - so build your army wisely! Roll and assign your command dice each round to determine when monsters move and fight. Roll your combat dice to resolve monster battles, leaving the defeated monster smashed on the battle map!

Are YOU powerful enough to collect and command the Necromolds?


∎ Mold 'em
Use your spellbooks to mold and mobilize an unstoppable monster army. The stronger the monster, the more clay it demands!

∎ Fight 'em
Roll and issue command dice to charge your minions into a chaotic fast-paced miniature wargame!

∎ Smash 'em
Destroy your fallen enemies by smashing them with your unique caster ring! Collect all 22!

∎ Recast 'em
Leave your magician's mark! Smashed monsters become bugs, critters, and mini-monstrosities!

∎ Paint 'em
When your clay dries, paint & create your own unique and unsightly terrors!


Necromolds will continue to grow with more monsters and more ways to play! Share your homemade Necromolds missions, scenarios, and rules with our communities!

boardgame.name: Animaru Wo-zu
アニマルウォーズ (ANIMAL WARS)
boardgame.description:
アニマルウォーズ (Animaru Wo-zu) ANIMAL WARS is a 2-player card game with a theme of animal survival.

There are 18 animal cards in this game, each of which has its own strength and special power. Players take four cards at beginning of the game.

Each round, players place their first cards in front of them, then reveal them. Then do the same for the second card.

Then players take turns choosing to play an additional card or not. This round ends when all players pass in a row.

Each time a card is revealed, if the card has 'When revealed' effect, resolve it immediately. Some cards have continuous effect which is active while revealed.

At the end of the round, you win a round if your total strength is greater than your opponent's. You score two victory points by winning the round. Some cards give you extra points if they survived the round.

The game ends when a player has accumulated five victory points. The highest scorer wins the game.

カードには強弱がありますが、使い時や組み合わせによって逆転可能です。
「切り札」の出し時を考察するジレンマを楽しめます。

boardgame.name: Monster Science
boardgame.description:
Monster Science is a game in which 2 players assume the roles of mad scientists. Their sole ambition: inventing the most frightening monster on earth. Locked in their secret basement laboratories, they labour well past midnight, tinkering with high voltage, mixing strange elixirs, stitching and strapping to bring life to the boil – every monstrous creation becomes more frightening than the last. Their reward? The title of Grand Re-animator. The mad scientist above all mad scientists, whose monsters are so frighteningly scary, they strike fear into the hearts of even the most hardened creature.

Game-play involves acquiring and building Monsters and Items and exhibiting monsters to your opponent and their own terrifying creations. Each monster inflicts Fright on another reducing Courage. When a monster or scientist loses all their Courage, they flee and are removed from the game. The last Scientist in the Arena is declared the winner.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: BannerWar
boardgame.description:
Tabletop wargame for mass battles, historical or fantasy. The 2 versions of the rule share the same principles for orders, combat and fire.

3 levels: from tactical to strategical.

Standard : ~13 units / ~1h
Epic : ~30 units / 2h
Legend: ~50 units / 3h

BannerWar is a fluid and balanced system. It incorporates combat and fire resolution suitable for tactical battles.
On a strategical level, the rules add orders and deployment principles.
It takes into account a wide variety of troops while keeping the rules simple.
Its army lists offer real options on a tactical as well as on a strategical level.
Faster than most, it does not require more figures than other rulesets.

—user summary

BannerWar comprend une version de règles Historique et une version Fantastique. Les deux versions utilisent les mêmes mécaniques de jeu pour les ordres, les combats et les tirs, cependant la version historique est plus détaillée sur la formation des armées, les manoeuvres stratégiques et la psychologie ; alors que la version fantastique est plus accentuée sur la diversité et l'originalité avec quelques règles spéciales qui donnent beaucoup de caractère aux unités.

La version historique offre des champs de bataille variés et très agréables, qui rendent les parties fortement stratégiques. Elle apporte la possibilité de garder des troupes en réserve, en renfort, en embuscade ou de les mettre en avant garde ou arrière garde. Cette version est accés sur le réalisme grâce aux règles d'ardeur et de résistance. Les unités se déplacent et combattent de manière historique sans être noyées de règles spéciales.

La version fantastique est allégée sur la stratégie des terrains et des corps d'armée. Les contraintes de déplacement et certaines phases de jeu sont moins détaillées pour faire place à des règles sur les Monstres, les Créatures Volantes, les unités mythiques, les Héros et la Magie.

Bien entendu comme le système de jeu est commun, il est tout à fait possible (et même recommandé à terme) de jouer la totalité des règles de BannerWar. Cela ne rend pas les parties bien plus longues ni moins fuides; et cela permet d'avoir un jeu historique ou fantastique d'un grand réalisme avec une diversité de troupes trés élevée qui se joue autant sur la partie tactique que stratégique.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Ekusu Furu-tsu
エクスフルーツ (EXCLUSIVE FRUIT)
boardgame.description:
エクスフルーツ (Ekusu Furu-tsu) EXLUSIVE FRUIT is a card game with a theme of exploration for fruits.

A rumor says that there are three islands in the distant ocean, where secret fruits grow. You try to collect fruits in these islands, but only one can enter each of these islands at a time.

Each player has four cards in their hand: three fruit cards (Red, Green, Blue) and pass.

Each round, three victory point cards are placed on the table face-up, attached to each island. Then players simultaneously play one card from their hand. For each island, if only one player played fruit card of that color, that player gain the victory point card attached to the island. If more than one player played the same island, no players gain the victory point card. If any player plays pass, that player gains two points.

After the sixth round, each player adds up their victory points, and conditional victory points awarded. The highest scorer wins the game.
user summary

boardgame.name: Baladana
boardgame.description:
Baladãna is a new and exciting strategy game for two players.
There are some obvious similarities with chess, however Baladãna is more abstract and even more complex and dynamic.
The biggest difference is that while in chess the way each playing piece can move is always the same, in Baladãna, the way figures can move is dynamic, determined by their 'powers'. The configuration of these powers, represented by the colored rings, is updated throughout the game - players can change the position of one ring as part of each move, placing up to 3 rings on any figure. When more rings of different colors are placed on a figure the powers combine.
The objective is to capture both of your opponent's golden rings.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Kyari- Pi-su
キャリーピース (CARRYPIECE)
boardgame.description:
キャリーピース (Kyari- Pi-su) CARRYPIECE is a game for children, in which you learn one-digit addition and carrying.

Each turn, you draw two cards from the deck and add up these numbers. Advance your pawn a number of spots equal to the ones digit of the total. You win the game if your pawn landed on the goal spot. You lose the game of your pawn passed through the goal spot.

This game has an advanced game mode.

Rules are simple enough for children, but adults can enjoy the game. Suitable for your children's first board game.
